paper_abstract: In this work we establish that the language MIX = {w is an element of {a; b; c}* vertical bar vertical bar w vertical bar(a) = vertical bar w vertical bar(b) = vertical bar w vertical bar(c)} and the language O-2 = {w is an element of {a; (a) over bar; b; (b) over bar} vertical bar vertical bar w vertical bar(a) = vertical bar w vertical bar((a) over bar) Lambda vertical bar w vertical bar(b) = vertical bar w vertical bar((b) over bar)} are 2-MCFLs. As 2-MCFL5 form a class of languages that is included in both the IO and OI hierarchies, and as O-2 is the group language of a simple presentation of Z(2) we exhibit here the first, to our knowledge, non-virtually-free group language (i.e. non-context-free group language) that is captured by the IO and OI hierarchies. Moreover, it was a long-standing open problem whether MIX was a mildly context sensitive language or not, and it was conjectured that it was not, so we close this conjecture by giving it a negative answer. paper_title: MIX is a 2-MCFL and the word problem in Z(2) is captured by the IO and the OI hierarchies
